The age of the earth is 4,540,000,000 years - and it is easy to prove that that estimate must be pretty damn close. The oldest (whole) rocks that have been found: 4,280,000,000-year old rocks in Nuvvuagittuq greenstone belt (exposed on the eastern shore of Hudson Bay in northern Quebec) and the 4,030,000,000-year old Acasta Gneisses (in northwestern Canada near the Great Slave Lake). Further: calcium-aluminium-rich inclusions - the oldest known solid constituents within meteorites that are formed within the Solar System - are 4,567,000,000 years old, giving an age for the solar system and an upper limit for the age of Earth.

An excellent analogy for the timescale of the Earth was taught to me in genetics by Professor Mohammad Noor from Duke University. He made a great analogy to counter the creationist argument that there hasn't been enough time for life to evovle to what it is today, by showing that they are making the same error in judgement that Dereck brings up here, we can't fathom the difference between millions and billions of years.
Consider the dog. Humans have domesticated dogs within the last 10,000 years. Yet, all the breeds we know of today are from within the last few centuries. If we go back a thousand years ago, there was really only one type of dog. So, let's assume that all the breeds, even those that are less than 100 years old, have been evolving from this original breed for a thousand years. Considering that life has been evolving on Earth for 3.5 billion years, if 1,000 years were 1 mm, then 3.5 billion years would be 3 and a half kilometers long. Imagine counting from 3.5 km, or 2.17 miles 1 mm, or 1/32 of an inch at a time. That's how long of a timescale we are talking here.

Also, a great note to the timeline. We are closer to the time of T-Rex than the T-Rex is to the Stegosaurus.

PEOPLE OF YOUTUBE! THE EARTH IS ~4.5 BILLION YEARS OLD! Now that I am not using caps let me debunk some myths:

Myth:
Carbon Dating is inaccurate
Truth: 
Carbon Dating is extremely accurate for the same reason atomic clocks are accurate, radioactive decay ALWAYS occurs at the same rate for a given isotope of a certain atom (i.e. carbon 14) and so we can determine nearly exact fossil and geological records

Myth:
There is very little sediment on the ocean floor because the Earth is only a couple thousand years old
Truth:
Subduction is the cycle of the ocean crust being recycled, which also means that sediment is recycled

Myth:
Bent rock layers mean that the Earth's mountains must still be young
Truth:
The bent rock layers are formed underground near the upper mantle where there is a lot of heat and magma, another explanation is that because the tectonic plates move so slowly, the rock can adjust. After all magma in the upper mantle behaves as a non-newtonian fluid.

Myth:
Soft tissues in fossils mean that the Earth must be young, otherwise they would decompose
Truth:
Since the fossils are buried in sediment and become rocks, bacteria and fungi die off and are not able to decompose the soft tissues. 

You can see the evidence clearly supports an "old Earth" the lost goes on but I think this is enough. If you are going to reply, say something useful, don't get angry, and we can have a civilized conversation.

Radiometric dating isn't the only method of determining the age of rocks. Other techniques include analyzing amino acids and measuring changes in an object's magnetic field. Scientists have also made improvements to the standard radiometric measurements. Sure thing. The half life of isotopes is very well documented. The simple version goes like this - As an isotope ages, the number of protons stays the same, but the number of neutrons decreases. Different isotopes have different decay rates, which is why we have multiple methods for measurement. For dinosaur bones, we use uranium-238, uranium-235 and potassium-40. That answers the radiometric dating question.

You just said that "both scales refer to a 'million' as the same thing (10^9)". That's wrong. Yes, both the long and short scales have the same definition for 'million', but it is 10^6, not 10^9. It's really simple: Short scale million = 10^6, Long scale million = 10^6. Short scale billion = 10^9, Long scale billion = 10^12. So, when the word "billion" is mentioned, it doesn't mean the same thing to everyone.

Not quite true.. The number values diverge starting at 1,000,000,000. The short scale system refers to this as a billion, while the long scale system calls this "a thousand million". S.S. "trillion" is akin to L.S. "billion", but both scales refer to a "million" as the same thing (10^9). You're right that the UK has different values, but only starting at 10^12. These people are still incorrect in the video.
